G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 2 & 8.proposition: Venue is proper in the Brockton Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 2 & 8 because the Premises are located in Brockton, Plymouth County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.raw_text: Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, is responsible for maintaining the Premises in compliance with the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., and other applicable laws and regulations, including the obligation to provide adequate hot water.

105 C.M.R. 410.190 (formerly 410.190, 41.proposition: Under 105 C.M.R. 410.190 (formerly 410.190, 410.200 & 410.201), an owner must provide and maintain facilities for hot water in every dwelling unit, and the hot water must be available at all times at a temperature and in a manner consistent with the Code.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, Massachusetts law implies into every residential tenancy a covenant of quiet enjoyment, which protects tenants from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of their premises caused by the landlord or by the landlord’s failure to fulfill legal duties.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 11.proposition: 2. G.L. c. 186, § 11 (implied conditions in leases; duties of landlord).

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: 3. G.L. c. 239, § 8A (tenant defenses and counterclaims, including breach of quiet enjoyment and sanitary code violations).

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The complete loss of hot water for a period of weeks constitutes a serious housing condition and a violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.190, and therefore a violation of Defendant’s statutory and common‑law duties as a landlord.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion treats the loss of heat and hot water as a material breach of the implied warranty of habitability and ties the landlord’s obligations to compliance with the State Sanitary Code, but it does not specifically hold that a complete loss of hot water for weeks, standing alone, is a violation of 105 C.M.R. 410.190. The factual recitation describes intermittent and inadequate hot water, and the analysis groups heat and hot water together as ‘serious defects’ and ‘substantial Sanitary Code violation[s]’ without parsing duration or issuing a discrete holding on hot‑water loss. Thus, while strongly suggestive authority, it does not squarely establish the precise proposition claimed.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201). The landlord can have no reasonable grounds to believe that noncompliance will be acceptable…. A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord’s failure to provide essential services required by law, including heat and hot water, after notice, may constitute an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the standard for liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and cites prior cases as examples, explicitly noting that a landlord’s failure to repair defects after notice has frequently been deemed to violate § 14. In doing so, it favorably cites earlier decisions (including habitability-type failures) as established applications of § 14, which encompass failures to provide essential services such as heat and hot water. Thus, the case affirms, as part of its reasoning, that post‑notice failures to provide legally required essential services can constitute interference with quiet enjoyment.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord’s failure to provide essential services required by law, including heat and hot water, after notice, may constitute an interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction, but in the context of excessive noise from a bar operated on nearby premises, not failure to provide essential services like heat or hot water required by law. While the court cites earlier Massachusetts cases involving lack of heat, light, and power as examples of conduct breaching quiet enjoyment, this case itself does not address statutory duties to provide heat/hot water after notice under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Thus it does not directly stand for the specific proposition claimed, even though it is consistent with that line of authority.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done. Charles E. Burt, Inc. v. Seven Grand Corp., 340 Mass. 124, 127 (1959) (failure to supply light, heat, power, and elevator services). Westland Housing Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942)...

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is violated where the landlord’s conduct, or failure to act in the face of a legal duty, results in a serious interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that a landlord’s failure to act, in the face of a duty, can violate the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment where it results in a serious interference with the tenancy. The court explains that liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 turns on whether the serious interference with the tenancy is the “natural and probable consequence” of what the landlord did or failed to do, and concludes that the landlord’s inaction in removing drug dealers from common areas, if proven, could constitute a breach. This aligns with the proposition that both conduct and failure to act can violate the covenant when they seriously interfere with use and enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … if the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 is violated where the landlord’s conduct, or failure to act in the face of a legal duty, results in a serious interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court squarely interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s quiet enjoyment provision, explaining that liability does not require malicious intent and that the statute incorporates the common-law concept of serious interference with tenancy through the landlord’s acts or omissions. It explicitly ties § 14 to the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment, which protects against acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leased premises, and holds Gem liable under § 14 for permitting repeated flooding that interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. This directly supports the proposition that a landlord’s conduct or failure to act in the face of a legal duty, resulting in serious interference with use and enjoyment, violates the covenant under § 14.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.… When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.… Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”}

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771, 774–77 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: A violation of the State Sanitary Code that results in significant impairment of the tenant’s use of the premises can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion describes serious State Sanitary Code–type conditions (vermin, lack of heat, etc.) and notes that the judge found both a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. However, the Supreme Judicial Court’s analysis in this excerpt is focused on the *measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability* in a subsidized tenancy, not on when such conditions constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. The court does not analyze or articulate a rule that a State Sanitary Code violation causing substantial impairment of use equals a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment; it merely acknowledges the trial judge’s finding and then avoids duplicative damages.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982). ... Wideman lived for two years in an apartment lacking heat, infested by vermin, and plagued by other serious deficiencies.

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 784–87 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: Even where a landlord claims to be “trying” to fix a problem, a prolonged and unremedied lack of essential services, such as hot water, after notice, constitutes an unreasonable interference with quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court held that the landlord’s failure to adequately correct serious conditions—including inadequate heat and hot water—after notice constituted a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, even though the landlord had made repeated (but ineffectual) repair attempts. The opinion emphasizes that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct and the foreseeable substantial impairment of the premises’ value, not on intent, and it treats this prolonged failure to restore essential services as an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment despite claimed repair efforts.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: 12. Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973) (warranty of habitability; role of sanitary code).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion (though from a concurrence/dissent) squarely discusses and accepts moving away from caveat emptor for residential leases and tying the landlord’s obligations to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and similar regulations. It characterizes the majority as adopting an implied warranty of habitability and repeatedly analyzes how the Sanitary Code sets minimum habitability standards and should define the landlord’s duties, thus directly addressing both the existence of a warranty of habitability and the role of the sanitary code in defining its content.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Since 1960 dwelling units have been subject to the State Sanitary Code… The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation… As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would… hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards….”
